Hello there! Welcome to your first lesson! This first lesson is made to introduce you to the wonderful world of Chinese! We wil explore topics like how to greet different age and friend groups among others. Click on a card to get more details and a quiz.

This here is an interesting phrase. "Ni means you", and "hao" means good. However, when you put these two together, you get hello. This provides some interesting insight into Chinese culture. Imagine a world where you say, “You are good” instead of saying hi. Kind of strange isn’t it?

In Chinese, hǎo can mean many things, though most commonly, good. In this case however, hǎo becomes an adverb which modifies the word after it, jiǔ. Jiǔ means long and bùjiàn literally means no see. So when hǎo modifies jiǔ, it means very, resulting in the phrase meaning, “long time no see”.
This one is pretty straight forward. Zǎoshang means morning and just like in “hello”, hao means good.

Just like the other phrases, nǐ means “you” and hǎo means “good”. The ma in this phrase is a word used to indicate a quiz. When you put it all together, you get “You good?” or more accurately, “How are you?”
The character wǒ means I or me and hén means very. When putting it together, you get “I’m very good” or “I’m great”.
Hái means “or” or “also” and kěyǐ means “ok” or “can” but combined together, these three words mean “alright” or “so-so”.
The word bù/bú means “no” or “not”, so Wǒ bù hǎo means “I’m not good.”
This phrase means “good night”. Wǎn means “late” and ān means "peaceful".
The word phrase Zàijiàn means goodbye or bye. When zàijiàn is used, it’s inferred the two people will meet again.
Míngtiān jiàn means see you tomorrow. As you may have noticed, it has the same jiàn from Zàijiàn, which means “meet”.
Wǒ means “I” or “me” and is used to refer to yourself.
Nǐ means “you”. An example is the phrase Nǐ hěn hǎo or “You’re great!”
Hé means “and”; it is used to connect multiple nouns. For example, Wǒ hé nǐ means “me and you”.
De is a word used to show possession and functions similarly to the “ ‘s” we see in English. An example is Wǒ de péngyǒu or “my friend”.
Ma is a word used to indicate a quiz like in the phrase nǐ hǎo ma?
Bù/bú both mean “no” or “not”.
Shì means “is”, “are”, or “am”. However, when saying “You are good” do not include “shì”. It’s grammatically correct to say Nǐ hěn hǎo not Nǐ shì hǎo.
The word yě means “also” and can be used to add on to a phrase.
Dé shows the degree of an adjective.
De is an auxiliary word that is used after a verb.
Shìde means “yes” or “yeah” and can be used to reply to yes or no quizzes.
Búshì means “no” or “nope”. The word bú gives you a hint at the meaning since is means “no” or “not”
The phrase xǐhuān means like. For example, Wǒ xǐhuān nǐ means “I like you”.
The phrase xièxiè means “thank you” or “thanks”. For a more formal thank you, say xièxiè nǐ.

Bú kèqì means “you’re welcome”, and is often used to reply to xièxie. Kèqì means means “manners” but in context it means “thanks”. You can also say 別客氣 Bié kèqì which essentially means “no need to say thanks”.
Duìbúqǐ means “sorry”. When saying “I’m sorry”, you don’t say wǒ duìbúqǐ; simply say duìbúqǐ.
To introduce yourself, use the phrase wǒ jiào followed by your name.
Méi means “no” or “don’t” and guānxì means “worry”. Combined they mean “don’t worry about it” or “it’s ok”, typically used after someone says sorry.
The phrase wǒ bù zhīdào means “I don’t know”. Also, the phrase wǒ zhīdào means “I know”.
The phrase wǒ ài nǐ means “I love you”. The word ài means “love”.
